TEXT: The applicant is a non - profit - making association with its seat in GPE .
It is represented before the ORG by Mr. PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .

The applicant association has the aims of , inter alia , creating accommodation for socially disadvantaged persons , of speaking out for the concerns of socially disadvantaged persons , refugees and foreign workers , and of creating possibilities of encounter and exchange with these persons . In order to achieve these objectives it runs a house in GPE , which offers accommodation for socially disadvantaged persons in particular for young people and foreigners . The chairman of the applicant association is also living there .
On DATE , in the late evening , police officers carried out a control in this house .

On DATE the applicant association lodged a complaint with ORG ( Unabhängiger Verwaltungssenat ) alleging violations of ORG CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Convention and of ORG zum PERSON des Hausrechts ) .
ORG held hearings on DATE and CARDINAL DATE . It heard the chairman of the applicant association , the police officers who had carried out the control and the mayor of GPE as witnesses .
On DATE ORG partly rejected the applicant association ’s complaint as being inadmissible and party dismissed it as being unfounded .

Having regard to the evidence taken , it found the following facts established . Following a number of complaints from neighbours about illegally resident foreigners , the mayor of GPE requested ORG ( Bezirkshaupt - mannschaft ) to carry out a control under ORG ( Meldegesetz ) . The control was carried out in TIME of CARDINAL DATE . The police officers were let into the house by some of the inhabitants . The chairman of the applicant association criticised TIME of the control but did not otherwise object . He contributed to the smooth carrying out of the control in that he went around with the police officers , gave general information about the inhabitants ( e.g. about their country of origin ) , acted as a translator and helped to produce the required documents . The rooms within the house were opened upon request . The police examined whether the foreigners were legally resident by controlling their identity documents and residence permits , or by checking the status of their asylum proceedings . A search of the rooms was not carried out . The control was terminated within DATE .

ORG found that the applicant association , being a legal person , did not have a private and family life . Thus it could not rely on LAW . Moreover , it had not claimed , and there was no indication , of any interference with its right to respect for its correspondence . Accordingly this complaint had to be rejected as being inadmissible .

As regards the control , ORG noted that also a legal person could rely on ORG . However , the said LAW only applied where a search had been carried out . As the police officers were voluntarily granted access to the house as well as to each of the rooms within the house and , assisted by the applicant association ’s chairman , only controlled the documents of the inhabitants , the contested action could not be qualified as a search . ORG added that the protection afforded by LAW went further , in that it covered not only a search of LOC but any interference with the right to respect for one ’s home . In the present case the control was in conformity with LAW , in particular it had its legal basis in ORG ) and LAW ( Fremdenpolizeigesetz ) . Consequently , the complaint had to be dismissed as being unfounded .
Further , ORG found that the applicant association , as a legal person , could not rely on LAW and , therefore , rejected this complaint as being inadmissible .

Finally , as to the complaint under LAW , ORG found that the control at issue was not aimed at the applicant association but at the inhabitants of the housing project , who were not even necessarily members of the applicant association . Moreover , the control did not prevent the applicant association from pursuing its objectives . Even assuming that there had been an interference with the applicant association ’s freedom of association , it had to be regarded as necessary in the interests of public safety . Having regard to the short duration of the control , it was also proportionate . Thus , this complaint was also unfounded .

On DATE the applicant association lodged a complaint with ORG ) . It relied on LAW . It argued that the control carried out in its premises had to be qualified as a search and that it lacked a legal basis . Further , it relied on LAW , claiming that the search prevented it from pursuing its objectives .

On DATE ORG refused to deal with the applicant association ’s complaint for lack of prospects of success . It noted that the case was not excluded from the jurisdiction of ORG ( Verwaltungsgerichtshof ) . Subsequently the Constitutional Court , upon the applicant association ’s request , referred the case to ORG .

On DATE the applicant association , upon ORG request , supplemented its complaint . It repeated its argument that the control had to be qualified as a search which lacked a legal basis , and added that there had not been any reasonable suspicion that foreigners were illegally resident on the LOC .

On DATE ORG rejected the applicant association ’s complaint as being inadmissible . It noted that the association relied on the right to respect for its home . This was a constitutionally guaranteed right which ORG was not called upon to review . The decision was served on DATE .
